georgica — SyncroBit 12/11/2020 12:54 PM
no that is not the idea, this is in addition to enable-ing verification of those said hotspots via a Golden gateway challenge, much like witnessing... So in essence this gateway will send a RF packet waiting for a response once it received the response it tells the consensus group "at this time, at these coordinates i found X hotspot is there and it provides coverage" (edited)

JMF 12/11/2020 1:42 PM
Just so I have it here for reference, here was my trust scoring system I've proposed a few times:
13:42
- Everyone starts with a 1.0 score - Score is reduced based on PoC activity (doesn't penalize loan wolves) - Positive verification brings score back up to 1.0 - Long wait times between when an individual golden tab/gateway can re-validate a specific gateway. - Rewards for the validation being an inverse of the score of the hotspot being validated, to incentivize going out of urban areas. If you're doing a ton of PoC activity you should in theory be worthy and able to get validated. It's also the reason I like the golden units to be mobile.
1
13:44
This is dependent on a willingness to shift a material % of POC earnings to this new bucket. Personally, I think it's more important than most POC.
1

georgica — SyncroBit 12/11/2020 3:09 PM
it is not really designed as mobile mapper, it is a gateway its main role is to stay planted, but it can be mobile, way i was envisioning this in terms of mobility is something like "patrons temporarily swap-ing out hotspots at their hosts". Reason why i went with gateways is because it required less effort to produce these concentrators than doing R&D on a complete new product, and it can be brought to the market quicker. (edited)

louis 12/11/2020 5:44 PM
IMO, whatever you want to do with a Golden Tab you can do better with a mobile anchor gateway. the benefits of an anchor gateway is that they simply have better RF front end (8 RX channel vs 1, fine grain GPS timestamping). Better RF front end means more information for the protocol to derive a reliable Trust Score

Joey 12/12/2020 10:39 AM
Unpopular opinion: I think this HIP makes great propositions on hardware design, but the idea of golden X feels wrong. I may have missed it, but I haven’t seen a scenario where this only benefits deployments in urban areas or the folks who are lucky enough to host one of these devices. How many of these devices would be in the wild? 20? 2,000? 200,000? At small quantities it would take years to validate even the core percentage of deployments. Maybe JMF will roadtrip his RV for the next two years, validating oil and gas fields in Canada, or pasturelands in Ireland - but I’d hazard to guess he’s got better things to do. At large quantities, it becomes a guarantee that these devices will fall into the hands of bad actors. Wherein, the device security aspect of this HIP is really the only deterrent. We don’t need to look much further than the mappers project to know how difficult it will be to consistently validate the network. (edited)

capcom 12/12/2020 1:47 PM

georgica — SyncroBit 12/12/2020 2:02 PM

capcom

GP 12/12/2020 3:43 PM
Thanks. I was wondering because if those are trusted nodes essential to functioning of network that would seem to suggest that they are a central authority. So, I am evidently not understanding their significance. Who will provide them after Helium the company is no longer involved? My understanding the network is intended to be entirely self-maintaining in due time.
capcom 12/12/2020 3:44 PM
Any full nodes can be used as the seed nodes. You could modify the configuration of your miner to point at any other hotspot and it would work fine. So quick answer is that anyone could run them
15:45
They are just a discovery mechanism
15:46
In any case, certainly not related to the HIP in question here
GP 12/12/2020 3:57 PM
Gotcha. I thought topic here concerned authoritative nodes entrusted with ability to certify_verify others, which sounded to me like nodes entrusted to honestly provide essential information to others. Hopefully eventually I will better understand the architecture. Thank you.
capcom 12/12/2020 4:02 PM
The only function the seed nodes serve is being the first p2p host your miner connects to. From there your miner discovers other nodes to connect to (via that node). And then other nodes from those nodes. And so on. That’s how the p2p mesh forms and eventually your node knows about a bunch of other nodes it can send and receive data through (called the peerbook). But at the initial start you don’t know where anyone is or how to connect to them. Most blockchain networks work the same way, including bitcoin. We will likely run our nodes forever, but anyone could do the same and configure their miners differently (edited)
GP 12/12/2020 4:12 PM
So, if your intention is to run seed nodes forever, why not other authoritative nodes? Every manufacturer of hotspots needs to hardcode in some address for seed node why not give greater functionality to those nodes? louis 01/26/2021 8:08 AM
With the content of the HIP no. The suggested improvement right now is just that, "We can inherently trust the data from Anchor Gateways so they're witnessing reports are worth more to us". I hope that's enough to start building and rolling out these modules in the short-term In the longer-term, I think these modules could be used to suss out such cheat clusters by making more elaborate POC games, such as the one you pitched in #hip-discussion with your google doc. Another approach would be as follows: with 3 Anchor Gateways that have fine timestamping capabilities, they could use differential time of flight (DTOF) to approximate location of the "emitter", even if the emitter is not secured and does not have GPS. Thanks to HIP17, cheatnets are forced to spread out, so even if DTOF isn't terribly accurate, it should help. That being said, I didn't want to bog this one HIP down with too many POC ideas, because I think what we're seeing lately in the community at short and precise HIPs with intent to layer improvements in further HIPs. Also, I frankly don't know how good DTOF could be on these SX1303s. (edited)

louis 01/26/2021 2:06 PM
To reiterate, the Anchor Gateway HIP as it stands makes no claim to stomp out the gaming problems. The only claim is that the proposed concentrator design is more secure and should earn more for witnessing. If Syncrobit wants to make the effort to develop the modules and DeWi agrees to audit and manage the secure provisioning, that is up to those parties whether they believe the effort worthwhile. louis 04/27/2021 11:31 AM
@para1 had some discussion/list of attack vectors previously, but I'm not sure if they covered physical RF. With regards to the remaining vectors once you more or less c close off simple SW manipulation, there may have been some discussion previously, but I can't find the record. Most of the vectors would center around putting the DIY concentrator into a faraday cage and echoing packets that perhaps a real gateway is seeing. Thus a single real gateway could capture enough "real world stuff" and it being relayed in a "believable way" to a DIY concentrator. We didn't cover GPS very much in this current HIP22 iteration, but the same things can be done there, even if we did add GPS. That being said, a GPS addition and some smart encryption and use of trust validators might start erecting some serious barriers to bad actors.

@crashpilot @jmarcelino ultimately, the MAX32510 is just an implementation choice made by @georgica — SyncroBit. if another vendor implemented a design with HIP22 compliant characterstics, it should also be certified. it would be practical as a community to select a first one that is more widely available (so many different firmwares don't require auditing and signing by DeWi), however, that selection is not necessarily within scope of the HIP

jerm 04/28/2021 7:42 PM

Tim | LongAP 04/28/2021 10:01 PM
Sorry, but that’s impossible, no hardware or software is free from side-channel leaks. Some ICs just have “easier” side channels (like power and timing) (edited)

What I'm missing currently from the HIP is more requirements/details of the provisioning part. I see three phases: 1: We accept HIP22 concentrators created by HIP19 manufacturers after light hardware/software security review by DeWi (a bit like HIP19 devices). DeWi is not involved in firmware signing/provisioning. This could be the solution for DIY and allows for new non-HIP19 manufacturers using HIP22 concentrators (that's basically just like DIY). I'm ok with this today. 2: The provisioning of HIP22 concentrators is stricter controlled (to avoid manufacturer cheating). DeWi verifies and signs firmware and staker (either manufacturer or 3rd-party) provisions the DeWi public-key irreversible on the secure MCU. In theory this is a nice improvement, but I don't see how this would work in practice. In practice manufacturers will "hire" a staker to hire an assembly company to do the provisioning (possibly even the same company doing PCBA for the manufacturer). Is this acceptable @louis? 3: Adjusting rewards for HIP22-based hotspots. As said before, I would only agree to do so after at least 6 months of lead time. If not you will probably bankrupt any manufacturer that already committed to production of non-HIP22 concentrators and is doing refunds of unshipped orders. (edited)

Tim | LongAP
What I'm missing currently from the HIP is more requirements/details of the provisioning part. I see three phases: 1: We accept HIP22 concentrators created by HIP19 manufacturers after light hardware/software security review by DeWi (a bit like HIP19 devices). DeWi is not involved in firmware signing/provisioning. This could be the solution for DIY and allows for new non-HIP19 manufacturers using HIP22 concentrators (that's basically just like DIY). I'm ok with this today. 2: The provisioning of HIP22 concentrators is stricter controlled (to avoid manufacturer cheating). DeWi verifies and signs firmware and staker (either manufacturer or 3rd-party) provisions the DeWi public-key irreversible on the secure MCU. In theory this is a nice improvement, but I don't see how this would work in practice. In practice manufacturers will "hire" a staker to hire an assembly company to do the provisioning (possibly even the same company doing PCBA for the manufacturer). Is this acceptable @louis? 3: Adjusting rewards for HIP22-based hotspots. As said before, I would only agree to do so after at least 6 months of lead time. If not you will probably bankrupt any manufacturer that already committed to production of non-HIP22 concentrators and is doing refunds of unshipped orders. (edited)
louis 04/29/2021 1:36 PM
At this point, I would simply omit 3 entirely from consideration. I think a rejiggering of rewards would only be on the table once some of these ideas are implemented and field-tested. I think you've delineated things in a very interesting way between your phase 1 and 2. Your definition of phase 1 actually makes me think that this could be done under the umbrella of HIP19 even. In which case, I would say the goal of this HIP would be to at least accomplish 2. My reasoning is that 1 on its own is simply too incremental. It doesn't meaningfully improve security, whereas providing special care around provisioning and firmware signing does.
In theory this is a nice improvement, but I don't see how this would work in practice. In practice manufacturers will "hire" a staker to hire an assembly company to do the provisioning
I am open to other ways of thinking about provisioning; this was just a naive attempt at defining something. The requirement of the "provisioner" proving ownership of 5 validators seems like a simple way to secure this step while also providing flexibility. To finally answer your question, I would think that that would be acceptable; the point to me is that the actor who is responsible for the provisioning step (likely engaging a CM) has a significant stake in the network, therefore maintaining its integrity of this step, which is our root of trust, is important to them

Tim | LongAP 04/30/2021 12:10 AM
I added phase 1 as a possible intermediate step to allow for quick DIY and non-HIP19-manufacturers before we flesh out the whole full HIP22 setup (if there is a manufacturer that has a solution "ready"). I agree that this could be done in a setup like HIP19 but there are some differences, because there are risks that non-HIP19-manufacturers sell products that are not compliant with Helium in other areas (frequency plans, miner performance, etc). Also it's important to note that those pre-HIP22 DIY concentrators are not upgradeable, so to avoid confusion, it's debatable if we would want this today. Ok, I can live with this staking requirement under these conditions. I did some thinking about the provisioning part. And without looking at a specific solution, all verified firmware/boot setups require the irreversible setting of some kind of public-key that corresponds to the private-key used to sign the firmware. Additionally within the same process the "provisioner" wants generate a private-key on-chip and attest the public-key. Currently we do this with the uploads to the DeWi onboarding server. The benefit of this setup is that DeWi can prevent additional keys to be added. I see three options: Option 1: The "provisioner" signs the public-key of the concentrator (and some additional data) into a certificate. The public-key of the "provisioner" is published on the blockchain in some way. During onboarding the concentrator-certificate can be verified in the CG (by using the provisioner public key). The good thing about this setup is that it is 100% chain-only. So no onboarding server required. The bad thing is that while we could add the option to revoke "provisioner" keys at a certain date, this would also affect any not-yet-provisioned concentrators, and it's impossible to monitoring the amount of concentrators provisioned
00:13
Option 2: Like option 1, but the certificates live on the blockchain (so like a provision_gateway transaction), this solves the monitoring part and makes revocation less painfull but adds some blockchain-size-bloat Option 3: We keep the current onboarding server setup at DeWi, but add a signature-verification step using the "provisioner" public-key

louis 05/27/2021 1:18 PM
I would argue that "HIPs with code only" should only apply to HIPs that have a blockchain impact and this one does not. We are modifying the social and trust model that we have hanging around the add_gateway transaction which currently is only defined in HIP19. Let me attempt to clarify lack of blockchain impact since it seems like I'm still failing: * there is no blockchain impact as this only changes the process of how swarm_keys are accepted onto the onboarding server * the swarm_key on the secure MCU may only sign certain transactions upon request (eg: add_gateway) and will emit POC witness and packet_offer signatures if and only if they correspond to rxpk frames it has observed from the SX13xx Therefore, nothing changes to the blockchain or the onboarding server logic other than a new category of maker that can upload to the onboarding server. HIP22 is an alternate to HIP19, which itself sets a very low bar in terms of specification, in my opinion. I admit, there is still a lot of vague "DeWi will review and approve" rather than specifying particular protocols or implementation. But similar to HIP19 it defines security properties that would be "HIP22 compliant". I would argue that leaving this HIP pending for the sake of more prescriptive specifications would delay people from actually building "HIP22 compliant concentrators" and would leave us dependent on HIP19 as the only way to get swarm_keys onto the onboarding server. I hope that one or two open-source proposals will be generated and that we will converge on some open-source designs/firmware that are HIP22 compliant and continue elaborating our security model from here. (edited)
Tim | LongAP 05/27/2021 1:47 PM
Thank you for the clarification. I would be interested in seeing if we can ensure that only the right transactions are being signed. This would require blockchain-transaction-knowledge to be implemented in the secure MCU (and has to be kept up to date by remote firmware updates). With regards to open-source designs. I think this would be of great value, just like the reference designs of Semtech are.

louis 05/27/2021 1:50 PM
This would require blockchain-transaction-knowledge to be implemented in the secure MCU (and has to be kept up to date by remote firmware updates).
Yes, that's exactly right. This is very similar to the Ledger hardware wallet security model; it is illegal to submit a "binary blob" to the secure MCU for signing. Instead, you submit the parameters of the transaction and the transaction is assembled and signed by the secure MCU. What is also specified in the HIP is that the secure MCU requires a secure firmware update feature where only signed firmwares may be loaded. We specify that these must be signed by DeWi.
Tim | LongAP
Thank you for the clarification. I would be interested in seeing if we can ensure that only the right transactions are being signed. This would require blockchain-transaction-knowledge to be implemented in the secure MCU (and has to be kept up to date by remote firmware updates). With regards to open-source designs. I think this would be of great value, just like the reference designs of Semtech are.
louis 05/27/2021 1:52 PM
With regards to open-source designs. I think this would be of great value, just like the reference designs of Semtech are.
I also believe that with this HIP in place, it makes it more straightforward for DeWi to potentially fund the development of open-source HIP22-compliant initiatives
louis

Tim | LongAP 05/27/2021 1:57 PM
The hard part about open-sourcing will be to find a trade-off between security and open-sourceness. For example MAX32510 including it’s SDK is under NDA. Do you think it would be acceptable to use a MCU that has an crypto-accelerator, but leave tamper-proofing to the final assembly? (for example by using potting)

Someone in the community who doesn't have context will come by and say "Hey so can I build DIY now that this is approved?" or "I'm a new manufacturer who doesn't want to go through this process of HIP19. Where can I buy a HIP22 concentrator and put it in my existing hardware?" (edited)

louis 05/27/2021 3:37 PM
I think we're concerned with very different people languishing with lack of direction. I'm mostly concerned with giving developers a mandate for what needs to be built. Hardware and firmware necessarily take more time than software, even if its blockchain software. In particular, we should not be prescriptive about hardware designs and this HIP already includes a block diagram for what would be a relevant hardware implementation. How are people going to spend the time to implement something, even a high level signing application, if there's no clear mandate on what a new security model is? This HIP is that definition. (edited)
hashc0de
With what we have today in this HIP a community "approval" is a signal to the community that we will accept "someone" investigating this kind of hardware. I can't imagine the downside given that it's a natural upgrade to the network so of course it'll be approved.
louis 05/27/2021 3:44 PM
I think we're mostly on the same page, @hashc0de. What's worth emphasizing is that this HIP is the only HIP since HIP19 to deal with the very muddy area of hardware/firmware/blockchain/KYC-with-DeWi. I think in this case, passing incremental HIPs that signal community consensus on these inter-disciplinary topics allows us to have a mandate and get things done.

kleonz

Tim | LongAP 06/10/2021 2:06 PM
if HIP22 is approved and if a HIP22 concentrator is designed and if a HIP22 concentrator is "certified" (both FCC/CE as DeWi) and if the gateway you are using (like Dragino LPS8) is hardware-compatible with the HIP22 concentrator and if the gateway you are using is software-compatible with the HIP22 concentrator, you will be able to earn for HNT proof-of-coverage as well by swapping the existing concentrator for a HIP22 concentrator, but it's a lot of if's (edited)

Carl-bot BOT 06/11/2021 4:51 AM
It looks like you're asking about the Dragino LPS8 which is a Data-Only Hotspot. You will not earn HNT for PoC and the amount of HNT earned for transferring data is small. For every DC used to transfer a packet, the Data-Only Hotspot will earn 1 DCs worth of HNT. 1 DC = $0.00001. Setting up a Dragino LPS8 is a great way to build network coverage, but will not earn HNT for Proof-of-Coverage For more information, please visit: https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/light-hotspots#data-only-hotspots
Light Hotspot Project (Beta) | Helium Documentation
This document describes the architecture and technical roadmap planned for converting exisiting Approved Hotspots to Light Hotspots. As part of this migration, we will also introduce a new Hotspot variant onto the network, called a Data Only Hotspot (more below).

gwbarbour821 07/24/2021 4:49 PM
The only thing I can think of is a network reaching a critical mass, so to speak, and each node (and by extension customer) being able to simultaneously make contact with two other WELL SEASONED AND TRUSTED nodes. Basically when there's enough paying customers, it will reach critical mass. So areas where there's no actual usage will be like the wild west until then, unless there's a genuine technical effort to resolve gaming. Or... maybe a GPS enabled network scanner that is rewarded with HNT for finding fake nodes. And it is required to have a continuity in its GPS coordinates and its relative position to the nodes that it tests. It wouldn't just have to make contact with a node, it would have to prove the GPS position of the nodes boundaries as it actively maintained contact with a real internet connection test server through the network. But even that could be cheated with enough sophistication. Untik critical mass, either incentive has to be given to exposing gamers, or the difficulty of gaming has to exceed economic viability. (edited)

22:40
Re de/centralized: Would be hell a lot more difficult to "fork" helium, since someone would have to provide LoRa console, router, network server, integrations, etc. A lot of that code is open source, but still the new fork would have to host those services. And hotspots themselves are at a given location, so (assuming similar reward model) if you move to the new chain, and your neighbors don't, then you would not get any PoC rewards.
22:40
And a fork would be a serious kick in the global / ubiquitous coverage part of helium...

Tim | LongAP 10/22/2021 10:50 AM
Currently it’s trivial to fake or adjust LoRa traffic by modifying it digitally with HIP19 hotspots, really the only security is that the hotspot-key is not exportable. It’s freely usable to cheat with however (by signing LoRa packets that are fake and not actually received) The secure concentrators fix that by “binding” the LoRa radio with the hotspot key so only valid packets can be signed.
Tim | LongAP
Currently it’s trivial to fake or adjust LoRa traffic by modifying it digitally with HIP19 hotspots, really the only security is that the hotspot-key is not exportable. It’s freely usable to cheat with however (by signing LoRa packets that are fake and not actually received) The secure concentrators fix that by “binding” the LoRa radio with the hotspot key so only valid packets can be signed.

Dinocore 01/04/2022 5:12 PM
do we have an RF engineers @here? I've done an analysis of the RF filter on the front end of Semtech's SX1303 reference design. This is what I get. Questions I have: 1) Did I setup the LTSpice simulation correctly? Is it correct to model the antenna with a 50ohm resistor? 2) This looks like a butterworth filter topology, but with the addition of C3. Why add C3? 3) can we do better? This cutoff frequency is around 1.7Ghz... that seems a bit too far from the desired cut off of ~950Mhz
Tim | LongAP 01/05/2022 2:42 AM
It seems that you only modelled theoretical components but left out their actual properties and the properties of the PCB stack-up itself.
Dinocore 01/05/2022 4:58 PM
yea so even after adding some reasonable guesses of parasitic properties from PCB it does not change much
16:58
im wondering if this front end filter is even really necessary
16:59
there is already a few SAW filters in the TX and RX path. Any ideas why this low-pass filter is part of the design?
Krassi 01/06/2022 8:33 AM
the SAW filter in the TX path is before the final PA(skyworks chip), the filter before the antenna is to filter out 2nd and 3rd harmonic
Krassi
the SAW filter in the TX path is before the final PA(skyworks chip), the filter before the antenna is to filter out 2nd and 3rd harmonic
Dinocore 01/06/2022 8:38 AM
2nd and 3rd harmonics while transmitting, correct? So then the filter before the antenna's purpose is really to meet FCC regulations. Thanks that makes sense. (edited)
Dinocore 01/06/2022 8:58 AM
@Krassi any thoughts on why C3?
Krassi 01/06/2022 9:07 AM
yes, i think by FCC rules the 2nd need to be suppressed to -50dB against the fundamental. C3 is to fix a dip/peak in the response curve(not visible in your simulation) maybe, idk
Dinocore 01/06/2022 9:40 AM
Got it. Thanks for your insight!
Krassi 01/06/2022 10:14 AM
you're welcome

Tim | LongAP 01/10/2022 4:42 AM
The difference between HIP22 and HIP19 is that with HIP19 you can only buy a "complete" hotspot because the whole OS is part of the secure context (and yes, somewhat flawed). With HIP22 concentrators the whole secure context is reduced to a secure microprocessor on the concentrator. This means that full hotspots don't need DeWi approval anymore (they still need FCC/CE certifications/testing) and somebody could build a DIY hotspot using such approved HIP22 concentrator.
Tim | LongAP

This means that full hotspots don't need DeWi approval anymore (they still need FCC/CE certifications/testing) and somebody could build a DIY hotspot using such approved HIP22 concentrator.

Tim | LongAP 01/10/2022 4:52 AM
No all software and hardware for HIP22 concentrators still needs to be developed (well at least most of it, work is being done). You need to be able to update the software on the concentrator because changes to the blockchain will happen and this needs to be done securely. Of course you can theoretically replace any microcontroller with a FPGA. But I don't see this as a viable option at all. FPGAs (especially in the size required) are not more well available than microcontrollers

Alexis 01/10/2022 5:02 AM
Well nowadays, no IC is easy to buy... Reprogramming an fpga is easy. We can think of a SoC board with rj45 and all the sensitive logic as RTL and the frontend(GUI) in the arm hps/cpu or an API directly in the FPGA. The advantage is that the bitstream of an FPGA is unreadable, even if you can readback the flash, you will never be able to see the netlists and clearly never be able to tamper the logic. It's like being encrypted by design. Let me read more the thread and the issue to see at which point this HIP is. (I believe the HIP22 can accept several designs if they commit to the specs) I'd like to avoid depending on third-party to build hotspots. The less we are dependent, the better it is.

WreckedAbandon 06/15/2022 1:27 PM
Being 62, and in the commercial broadcasting industry, I vividly remember the lengths folks would go to steal satellite services / HBO, Showtime, etc.- The General Instruments Videocipher II module, (circa early 80's-90's) which was part of most home satellite systems, had such a conformal coating - This didn't stop folks from finding out what they needed to dissolve it - Nothing is completely secure but yes, you should attempt to make the board as hack-resistant as possible.

Sloth 06/16/2022 12:39 PM
Order just the dies of the two micro's and do the wirebonding on PCBA level. This way you will have ridiculous short traces with weak gold wires in an epoxy blob. It's difficult to remove this epoxy without damaging the PCB and wirebonds and currently it costs a lot of money to have this done(in the terms of hundreds of dollars per unit) as it involves not so nice chemicals. This does require large board quantity per run. Or at least burry all the sensitive traces and via's in a multilayer PCB. This requires to desolder the chip if you want to middleman it. But is a huge effort if you go the BGA package route. (edited)
2
Sloth

1
Sloth 06/16/2022 1:07 PM
It's usually done for cheaper stuff(like bluetooth trackers) as you need the manufacturer to be willing to sell you dies and not all do. But even carefully selecting the right potting compound can make it a nightmare to hack into a board. It's no fun to decap an IC(using nitric or sulfuric acid) or similar compounds. If someone goes through that trouble successfully they've earned it. Conformal coating like mentioned is way, way easier to remove. (edited)

Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 12:34 PM
Hey @Dinocore we've looked at your design again with the team, and have concerns about the performance of packet delivery in your setup
12:34
Did you look at this?
12:34
For example how many signature's (and therefore packets) can you produce per second?
12:35
Are you planning to filter and only sign beacons?
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:43 PM
My firmware right now signs every received packet. When a packet is received, It simultaneously delivers the packet immediately to the host controller, and queues the packet for signing. A packet takes about 2-3 seconds to create the signature (which is not great) When the signature is complete, it then sends the signature to the host controller.
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 12:44 PM
And can your code handle other packers during those 2-3 seconds of signing?
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:44 PM
yes, the packets are queued on the SMCU for signing on another thread. It does not block other incoming packets.
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 12:45 PM
Well, is the SMCU single core?
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:45 PM
yes, but its running FreeRTOS
12:47
I could put together a demo showing this off
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 12:47 PM
Yes, but it doesn't magically give you extra processing power. Basically you can only process 1 packet per 3 seconds. And a SX1302 can process 100+ packets per second
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:50 PM
true, and if the SX130x is receiving packets at a rate faster then it can sign them, it will eventually fill the queue and not sign any new packets (it will continue to deliver the packet to the host controller, just not sign them). If this becomes a problem, it would be trivial to create a filter and let the host controller tell the SMCU to skip signing anything other than what is important (edited)
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 12:50 PM
Our approach only signed when asked, maybe something to consider?
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:52 PM
I took the the opposite approch: sign everything, unless asked not to (edited)
Ghost 06/22/2022 12:52 PM
Tim do you I need popcorn?
Dinocore 06/22/2022 12:57 PM
I love that you looked at the design! Did your team have any other feedback?
Ghost

Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 1:30 PM

1
2
Dinocore
I took the the opposite approch: sign everything, unless asked not to (edited)
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 1:33 PM
Yeah, but that requires a lot of computing on the MCU, additionally it can also introduce extra delays because the signing is not interruptable by FreeRTOS at any time (unless you use interrupts for SPI). Anyway our worry was that this won't perform. That's what we wanted to get across
Dinocore 06/22/2022 1:37 PM
I like it. I remember when we were talking about this a few months ago and I tried to explicitly address this concern when writing this firmware. That's why I implemented this signing-queue system. (edited)
Dinocore
I love that you looked at the design! Did your team have any other feedback?
Tim | LongAP 06/22/2022 2:07 PM
So on the hardware side we had a number of remarks: - Add stiching via's around RF traces and round RF traces. - Consider switching to a 6 layer board. Your top layer has a lot of SPI traces and other traces over a cross-power-plane causing EMI and possible interference issues - Your decoupling caps are placed "after" the via and far away in most cases, normally you place them between the via and the IC and as close as possible. - The TXCO is placed far away, can't you place this closer? - Ground the mini-pcie screw holes (edited)
1
Dinocore 06/22/2022 2:20 PM
Aweseome, thanks so much for the feedback. I will def incorporate this into the next revision. Especially the SPI traces crossing over the power-plane...thats no good. (edited)

waveform 10/05/2022 10:06 AM
Could software tell the difference between a denylisted RAK/MNTD and a RAK7248 LoRaWAN gateway both with a Secure concentrator, yes i'm sure and that has a cost. But could this be overridden, yes i'm sure again but again at what effort and cost. We could have a software solution to enquire if the hotspot has an existing ECC chip and then to check that against a denylist before it beacons. But could this be overridden by the simple act of desoldering the ECC chip? But step back from this, if a denylisted hotspot is fitted with a secure concentrator then it can only be deployed in a valid configuration or it will not earn. It cant be reused in a cheating cluster, that's one of the design features. So it will encourage the reuse of the 10s of thousands of denylisted hardware to be deployed correctly.
